verses.text: Guard your steps when you go to the house of God. Draw near to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they are doing evil.
verses.comment: Coming humbly to God's presence is a central theme. The 'house of God' at the time referred to the Temple, foreshadowing later the deeper reality of being reverent before God in worship, especially through communal liturgy. The 'sacrifice of fools' emphasizes that external acts without inner conversion are worthless (see Matt. 15:8).

verses.text: Do not be quick with your mouth, nor let your heart be hasty to utter words before God. For God is in heaven, and you are on earth—so let your words be few.
verses.comment: The warning against rash speech before God highlights humility and reverence. This attitude toward prayer and worship is later echoed in Christ's teachings about prayer (Matthew 6:7).

verses.text: For dreams come through much effort, and a fool’s voice through many words.
verses.comment: This verse compares excessive striving or talking to meaningless dreams, warning against empty verbosity both in prayer and pursuit of earthly things. Implies deeper meaning: inner stillness is the path to wisdom.

verses.text: When you make a vow to God, do not delay in fulfilling it; for He has no pleasure in fools. Fulfill what you vow.
verses.comment: Vows were solemn promises often associated with worship. Fulfillment of vows is a sign of genuine devotion. The seriousness of promises to God foreshadows the importance of sacramental promises and faithful commitment.

verses.text: It is better that you do not vow than that you vow and not fulfill it.
verses.comment: Echoes Christ's later teaching about oaths: integrity surpasses empty promises. Spiritual maturity lies in honest faithful action rather than rash speech.

verses.text: Do not allow your mouth to lead you into sin, and do not say to the messenger that it was a mistake. Why should God be angry at your voice and destroy the work of your hands?
verses.comment: Highlights responsibility for words spoken and the seriousness of commitments. The 'messenger' may refer to the priest or temple officer, enforcing accountability to spiritual authority—important in community worship.

verses.text: For when dreams abound and words multiply, there is emptiness. Fear God.
verses.comment: The conclusion: fearing God is greater than all vain dreams and empty speech. Reverence is central to wisdom and true worship, reminiscent of the call to fear God throughout Scripture.

verses.text: If you see oppression of the poor and the perversion of justice and righteousness in a province, do not be amazed at the matter; for the highest official watches over the high, and there are officials over them.
verses.comment: There is a hierarchy of authority in earthly governments, but ultimately justice flows from God's sovereign order. Spiritual interpretation: even in injustice, one trusts that divine providence oversees all.

verses.text: The profit of the land is for everyone; even the king is served by the field.
verses.comment: Points to a universal dependence on God’s provision. Everyone, from peasant to ruler, relies on creation’s fruit—echoing Genesis 1:29 and implying stewardship and thanksgiving as a form of worship.

verses.text: Whoever loves money will not be satisfied with money, nor he who loves abundance with gain; this also is emptiness.
verses.comment: Materialism is exposed as empty—true fulfillment comes from worshiping God, not possessions. Christ’s warnings about wealth align with this wisdom.

verses.text: When goods increase, those who consume them increase. So what advantage does their owner have, except to see them with his eyes?
verses.comment: Temporary wealth attracts dependents and expenses, offering no true lasting benefit. This points spiritually to storing up treasures in heaven rather than on earth (Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: Sweet is the sleep of a laborer, whether he eats little or much; but the abundance of the rich will not allow him to sleep.
verses.comment: A simple life with honest labor is blessed with peace; wealth brings anxiety rather than rest. This aligns with the spiritual principle of detachment.

verses.text: There is a grievous evil that I have seen under the sun: riches kept by their owner to his harm.
verses.comment: Hoarding wealth leads to spiritual decay—pointing to the need for generosity and sharing, especially in the faith community and serving others.

verses.text: Those riches perish through misfortune, and if he has a child, there is nothing in his hand.
verses.comment: Earthly possessions are fleeting and uncertain. This calls for placing trust in God and prioritizing spiritual inheritance over material gain.

verses.text: As he came from his mother’s womb, naked shall he return, to go as he came. He shall take nothing for his labor, that he may carry away in his hand.
verses.comment: The cycle of life and death is a reminder that only spiritual treasures last—echoed in Christ’s teaching about storing up heavenly treasures.

verses.text: This also is a grievous evil: exactly as he came, so shall he go; and what profit has he who toils for the wind?
verses.comment: Futility of earthly striving points to the need for faith, hope, and love as the lasting virtues, which are foundational for true fulfillment and community.

verses.text: All his days he eats in darkness, with much frustration, sickness, and anger.
verses.comment: Spiritual darkness results from materialism and is healed only through life in the light—participating in divine life through worship and sacramental fellowship.

verses.text: Behold, what I have seen to be good and fitting is to eat and drink and enjoy all the labor in which one toils under the sun, during the short days of his life which God has given him—for that is his lot.
verses.comment: Gratitude and enjoyment of daily blessings acknowledges God as the giver. This anticipates the spiritual practice of thanksgiving and celebration in worship.

verses.text: Moreover, to every man to whom God gives wealth and possessions, and empowers him to eat of it and to take his portion and rejoice in his labor—this is a gift of God.
verses.comment: Life’s gifts come from God, to be enjoyed in gratitude and humility, forming the basis of stewardship and communal responsibility in faith.

verses.text: He will not much remember the days of his life, because God keeps him occupied with joy in his heart.
verses.comment: The fullness of joy is found in God and in living according to His will. Spiritual interpretation: the soul at peace with God transcends worries, echoing the promise of joy given by Christ to His disciples.
